title: Use endpoints
content:
To set up an integration with an on-premises application through the On-Premises Bridge (OPB) agent, you must add an endpoint. Additionally, if you want to run REST calls without using the OPB agent or to set up an integration based on the Integration Studio, you also must add an endpoint. 

The following endpoint types are available:

  • UCMDB 10.20 and later: used to set up an integration with classic UCMDB for Configuration Item (CI) synchronization
  • Knowledge Indexing: used to set up an integration to index knowledge articles from other applications such as SharePoint and Confluence into Service Management so that agent users and Service Portal users can access them through search
  • Email Integration: used to set up an integration with an inbox on an external mail server so that users can request appropriate knowledge articles, create requests, and add comments or accept solutions to existing requests without the need to log in
  • REST Executor 1.0: used to run REST calls through the OPB agent. Also used in DND to fetch the data made available in a REST API. 
  • REST Executor 2.0: used to set up an endpoint for integrations based on the Integration Studio
  • Agentless REST Executor 1.0: used to run REST calls without the need for the OPB agent
  • Operations Orchestration: used to set up an integration with classic Operations Orchestration
  • PPM Outbound Integration and PPM Optimization Solver: used to set up an integration with Project Portfolio and Management (PPM)
  • LDAP Integration: used to set up an integration with an LDAP server for user synchronization

The following endpoints are also available if you have the DND capability installed and enabled.

  • LDAP Query: used to fetch values from the LDAP server.
  • JDBC Query: used to fetch data from a database server. 
  • File system: used to fetch the content from a file.
Note Each endpoint configuration described below is only part of their specific integration setup. For more information about the entire setup procedure of each integration, see the topics listed in the Related topics section. 

To add and configure an endpoint, follow these steps.

Add an endpoint

  1. From the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Integration. Click the Endpoints tab.

  2. Click Add.

  3. Enter the endpoint details.

    Field Description
    Endpoint type Select the application that you want to use to synchronize data.
    Endpoint name Enter a name for the endpoint. Use only Latin letters and spaces.
    Running on agent

    Select an agent from the drop-down list. These are agents that were installed using the On-Premises Bridge Agent.

    Note This field is not available for these endpoint types:  Agentless REST Executor 1.0, and  REST Executor 2.0. 
  4. Click Add.

Configure an endpoint

  1. From the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Integration. Click the Endpoints tab.

  2. Click Configure. The Endpoint Configuration dialog box opens.

  3. Enter the endpoint details. See the Endpoint details section below. 

  4. For UCMDB, Operations Orchestration, Email integration, PPM Outbound Integration, and LDAP integration, you can click the Test connection button to test the connection to the server.

    Note For Operations Orchestration, a test connection task is run automatically when you save the configuration.

  5. When you are finished, click Save.

Endpoint details

You can find the configuration settings based on endpoint types.

UCMDB 10.20 and later

See Integrate with classic UD/UCMDB.

Knowledge Indexing

Field Description
Endpoint name

The name of the endpoint. This field is read-only.
Indexing shared folder Specify the shared folder that the IDOL connector uses to save files.

Email Integration

Caution

  • Do not use the same email account for testing as will be used in your production environment. An email that's processed in your development environment will not be processed again in your production environment.
  • Each endpoint must use a unique email account, even on the same tenant.
Field Description
Mail server connection configuration (for SMTP & IMAP/POP3 mail servers)
Endpoint name The name of the endpoint. This field is read-only.
Mail protocol Select SMTP & IMAP/POP3 if you are configuring an integration with a mail service based on the SMTP & IMAP/POP3 protocol.
IMAP/POP3 server Enter the name or IP address of the IMAP or POP3 server.
SMTP server

Enter the name or IP address of the SMTP server.

Note To send emails using SMTP protocol, you must have STARTTLS enabled. This means that you must configure an appropriate trust store so that the client will trust the server's certificate. If STARTTLS isn't enabled, error messages might not be sent in cases where there was an error in handling emails.
Read messages protocol Select the protocol for reading emails. Both IMAP and POP3 protocols are supported. For a secure protocol, select IMAPS or POP3S. 
If you select the POP3 or POP3S protocol, the Remove emails from server after processing option is displayed. If you enable this option, once processed, emails will be removed from the inbox on the external mail server.
Credentials Choose the credentials to be used to connect to the email server from the drop-down list. The full credentials are those defined as part of the agent to which the endpoint is connected.

Mail server connection configuration (for EWS mail servers)

You can use OAuth 2.0 Resource Owner Password Credentials (ROPC) or OAuth 2.0 client credentials for integration with Microsoft Exchange Online. See Authenticate an EWS application by using OAuth for more information about OAuth authentication.

Keep a record of Application (client) ID, client secret, and Directory (tenant) ID that can be retrieved from Azure Active Directory admin center.
Endpoint name The name of the endpoint. This field is read-only.
Mail protocol Select EWS if you are configuring an integration with an Exchange Online service based on Exchange Web Services (EWS).
Mail server host Enter the name or IP address of the EWS server. This is the domain part of the EWS service URL.
Service path Enter the remaining part of the EWS service URL. Example: EWS/Exchange.asmx.
Application (client) ID Enter the value of the Application (client) ID.
Directory (tenant) ID Enter the value of Directory (tenant) ID.
Version Select the version of Exchange Server. If you are unable to find a match, select the latest version prior to the version of your Exchange Server.
Authentication method

Select an authentication method.

  • OAuth 2.0 ROPC: select this method if you have delegated mailbox permissions of Exchange services.
  • OAuth 2.0 client credentials: select this method if you have administrator permissions of Exchange services.
Mail from
(for OAuth 2.0 client credentials only)		 Enter the email account that the email integration monitors for incoming emails. The integration processes all emails received by this email account.
Credentials Choose the credentials to be used to connect to the email server from the drop-down list. The full credentials are those defined as part of the agent to which the endpoint is connected.
Advanced Connection Configuration
Proxy host Enter a valid address for the proxy server.
Proxy port

Enter the port number listened to by the proxy server (specified in the Proxy host field). The default is 1080 (for SMTP & IMAP/POP3) or 8080 (for EWS).

Note Leave this field blank if you aren't using a proxy server.
IMAP/POP3 port

Enter the port number listened by the email server. The defaults are:

  • IMAP, non-secured - 143
  • IMAP, secured - 993
  • POP3, non-secured - 110
  • POP3, secured - 995
SMTP port Enter the port number listened by the email server. The default is 25.
Authorized email domains Specify the email domains that are authorized to send emails to the email account specified for the integration. Emails from unauthorized domains will be rejected. The email account specified for the integration is authorized by default. If a user wants to add additional domains, specify them here, separated by commas.
Integration configuration
New email action

Specify how the receipt of the first email message will be handled:

  • Create request mode - each initial message automatically results in the creation of a new request.
  • Sent knowledge article and offering suggestions mode - each initial message receives an email response that contains possible suggestions.
Inbox poll interval (minutes) Choose the frequency for the email server to be polled for messages from the drop-down list. The default value is 1 minute.
Processed emails folder Specify the folder in the email account to which processed messages will be moved.

Note: if you use the POP3 or POP3S protocol, this option doesn't take effect due to a protocol limitation.
Error emails folder Specify the folder in the email account to which messages with errors will be moved.

Note: if you use the POP3 or POP3S protocol, this option doesn't take effect due to a protocol limitation.
Offering

Specify the default offering to be used when a request is created.

This field appears only when the New email action field is set to Create request. Offerings matching the following conditions are listed:

  • The status of an offering is Active or Internal.

  • The status of an offering’s service is Active.

  • The value of the IsAllowCreateRequestWithEmail field for the offering is True.

Note After configuring an email integration endpoint for the first time, it may take up to 30 minutes for the task to start.

Rest Executor 1.0

Field Description
Endpoint name

The name of the endpoint. This field is read-only.
Location

Enter the URL of the remote server to which you want to direct the REST call, including the protocol, host, port, and root context, if any.

If the URL uses HTTPS, make sure the host value is the same as the value of the Subject field of the corresponding certificate.
Credentials

Select the credentials to be used for the authentication of the remote server.

Note If a text field appears, insert the credential ID manually.

Rest Executor 2.0

This endpoint type is used to set up an integration based on the Integration Studio. For details, see Integration Studio. 

Agentless Rest Executor 1.0

Field Description
Endpoint type Select Agentless Rest Executor 1.0.
Endpoint name Enter a name for the endpoint. Use only Latin letters and spaces.

Operations Orchestration

Field Description
Endpoint name

The name of the endpoint. This field is read-only.
Location

For standalone Operations Orchestration - 

Enter the URL of the Operations Orchestration server in the format

http(s)://<operations_orchestration_server>:<port>

For example: If <server> = myhost.mycompany.net, <port> = 8444, the URL will be https://myhost.mycompany.net:8444

For Operations Orchestration embedded in Design and Deploy - 

Enter the URL of the Operations Orchestration server in the format

http(s)://<operations_orchestration_server>:<port>/<tenantid>

For example: If <server> = myhost.mycompany.net, <port> = 443 and <tenantid> = 246687036, the URL will be https://myhost.mycompany.net:443/246687036
Credentials

The list of credentials is populated automatically. Service Management queries the OPB agent for the list of credential records that were created in the Endpoint Credentials Manager.

If no credentials are received, there may be a problem with agent setup and authentication with Operations Orchestration.

You must select a user account that has the following Content permissions: View Content Packs, View Configuration Items, Manage Content Settings, Manage Content Packs, and Manage Configuration Items.

Operations Orchestration Containerized

For information on how to configure the Operations Orchestration Containerized endpoint, see Perform an integration with Operations Orchestration Containerized.

PPM Outbound Integration

Field Description
Endpoint name

The name of the endpoint. This field is read-only.
Location Enter the base URL of the PPM server to be synchronized with Service Management.
Credentials

Select credentials to be used for the authentication of the PPM server.

Note If a text field appears, insert the credential ID manually.
Enable manual sync Select Yes or No. If Yes is selected, the Sync now button appears in each idea and proposal record for you to manually synchronize each record to the PPM server. If No is selected, the record-level synchronization function is disabled.

PPM Optimization Solver

Field Description
Endpoint name

The name of the endpoint. This field is read-only.
Path

Enter the path to the installation of the COIN-OR Optimization Suite on your local computer.

The default path is: C:\Program Files (x86)\COIN-OR\1.8.0\win32-msvc12\bin\cbc.exe
Timeout Specify a numeric timeout value for the optimization. The recommended value is 30 (seconds).

LDAP Integration

Field Description
Connection configuration
Endpoint name

The name of the endpoint. This field is read-only.
Host name Enter the name or IP address of the LDAP server.
Port

Enter the number of the port listened to by the LDAP server. The default is 389.
Credentials

Enter the credentials used to connect to the LDAP server. The full credentials are those defined as part of the agent to which the endpoint is connected.

On the Microsoft Active Directory server, both Distinguished name and username login are supported. On the Apache DS server, only Distinguished name login is supported.
Scheduled integration interval

Select the interval between successive runs of the integration. The default value is 1 day.

For example, if the current sync finishes at 10:00 AM on Monday, and the Scheduled sync interval is 1 day, the next sync will run at 10:00 AM on Tuesday.
Encrypted connection

Select this check box to run the sync using SSL encryption.
Integration configuration
LDAP Server type

For supported LDAP servers, see the support matrix.
Starting search directory The root directory on the LDAP server where the data is stored.
Record to record mapping
Target record Select Person or Group.
Source record Enter the corresponding record type from LDAP.
Filter

The default filter is based on the selected record type (person or group). You can enter a custom filter to specify the relevant records for the integration.

Example:

To sync all people from groups 1 and 2 only, enter: (&(objectClass=person)(&(group=group1)(group=group2))).

To sync all people in either level 1 or level 3, enter:(&(objectClass=person)(|(level=level1)(level=level3))).
<Field mappings>

In each section, complete the following:

  • Target fields. Select the record fields from Service Management to be mapped.

    If you select a field of type Enum, click the arrow button next to Map values. Select the target values from the drop-down list and enter the source values from LDAP. Click Add value mapping to add additional value mappings.

    Note It's possible to map multiple source values to the same target value.

  • Source fields. Enter the corresponding fields from LDAP for the mapping. You can enter the fields in simple text or an Expression Language phrase.

    Click the Expression Language button to toggle between these options. When the button is selected (blue), the field is in Expression Language mode. When it's not selected (white), the field is in Simple mode. For a full list of Expression Language functions, see Expression Language functions and syntax.

  • Mapping condition. Optionally, enter an Expression Language phrase defining a condition. The mapping applies only when the condition is satisfied.

In each section, three default fields are provided. Click Add field to add additional field mappings. Click Remove next to any mapping to remove it.

Important You must include mappings for all fields defined as mandatory for the selected record type.

JDBC Query

Field Description
JDBC URL JDBC URL Examples:
jdbc:postgresql://<host_name> or <ip_address>:5432/mydb
jdbc:oracle:thin:@//<host_name> or <ip_address>:1521:XE
jdbc:sqlserver:////<host_name> or <ip_address>:1433/mydb
 
Credentials Endpoint credentials specified in Credentials Manager.

Note that only Postgres with SSL is supported.
For Oracle and SQL servers, ensure that you have copied the JDBC driver .jar file of the respective database to <OPB installed path>/product/domain/jdbc-query/lib  and restarted the OPB agent service.

LDAP Query

Field Description
LDAP URL

Specify the LDAP URL in the following format if the LDAP is SSL enabled: ldap(s)://<host_name> or <ip_address>:<port>.

Example for SSL-based URL: ldaps://<host_name> or <ip_address>:636

Example for non-SSL URL: ldap://<host_name> or <ip_address>:389

For SSL-based URLs, use only FQDN in the URL.
Credentials Endpoint credentials specified in Credentials Manager.

Note that the maximum limit of messages is 64 KB. You can use the attribute filter to bring only the mentioned attributes in response, to limit the LDAP response size.

File System

Field Description
File base path

The base path of the file from which you want the system to read the data.

This is only applicable to the files physically available in the OPB agent server.

The file can reside anywhere on the system.

Examples:

  • Linux: /usr/tmp
  • Windows: C:\Temp 
Credentials Endpoint credentials specified in Credentials Manager.

The file system endpoint supports read operations only.

Manage your endpoints

Select an endpoint in the Endpoints pane to manage it.

You have the following options for managing your endpoints:

Label Description
Set as default Specifies that the selected endpoint will be used by default in future synchronizations for the specified endpoint type. If a task is submitted without specifying a target endpoint, the default will be used.
Disable/Enable Disables or enables the selected endpoint. If you disable an endpoint, no new tasks can be submitted to it. If you disable an endpoint that has running tasks on it, the tasks will continue to run.
Remove Removes the selected endpoint from the list of endpoints. You can remove an endpoint only if all tasks on it have been completed.
Refresh Refreshes the list of tasks.
Stop/Start

For email integration endpoints only

  • Stop. Stops the polling of the mail server for email integrations. The task continues to run, but no emails are retrieved from the mail server.
  • Start. Restarts the polling of the email server, according to the value set for the Inbox poll interval in the endpoint configuration.

Note If any values of the email integration endpoint are changed without stopping and restarting the polling, it might take up to 30 minutes for the new values to take effect.

Configure a proxy for an endpoint type if necessary

You can configure a proxy for the On-Premises Bridge endpoint types (domains) in the <Agent Folder>\product\conf\wrapper-custom.conf configuration file.

Caution When OPB is deployed on Linux, don't include quotation marks in the parameter values in the wrapper-custom.conf file. When uncommenting a parameter line, remember to remove the quotation marks). For example:

  • Windows: -Dopb.executor.RestExecutorDomain-1.0.remote.debug.params="-agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,address=8000,suspend=n"
  • Linux: -Dopb.executor.RestExecutorDomain-1.0.remote.debug.params=-agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,address=8000,suspend=n

The following parameters are available for the proxy:

  • opb.all.executors.params. Contains the environment variables for all the executors.
  • opb.executor.<specificDomainName>.params. Contains the environment variables for the executor of a specific domain. It overrides similar parameters from the opb.all.executors.params.
  • opb.executor.<specificDomainName>.remote.debug.params. Contains the remote debug parameters for the executor of a specific domain.

Configure a proxy for the Rest Executor 1.0 domain

In the following example, we add a proxy configuration for all the domains, and override the ports only in the RestExecutorDomain-1.0 domain:

-Dopb.all.executors.params="-Dhttp.proxyHost=web-proxy.example.com -Dhttp.proxyPort=8080 -Dhttps.proxyHost=web-proxy.example.com -Dhttps.proxyPort=8080"
-Dopb.executor.RestExecutorDomain-1.0.params=”-Dhttp.proxyHost=web-proxy.example.com -Dhttp.proxyPort=9999 -Dhttps.proxyHost=web-proxy.example.com -Dhttps.proxyPort=9999"
To add a remote debug configuration for the executor process of the RestExecutorDomain-1.0 domain, use the following line:
-Dopb.executor.RestExecutorDomain-1.0.remote.debug.params="-agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,address=8000,suspend=n"

Configure a proxy for the Rest Executor 2.0 domain

Use the following configuration in the <Agent Folder>\product\conf\wrapper-custom.conf configuration file (replace the proxy host name and port with your own ones):

wrapper.java.additional.210=-Dopb.executor.RestExecutorDomain-2.0.params="-Dhttp.proxyHost=<proxyServerName> -Dhttp.proxyPort=<proxyServerPort> -Dhttps.proxyHost=<proxyServerName> -Dhttps.proxyPort=<proxyServerPort>"

To add a remote debug configuration for the executor process of the RestExecutorDomain-2.0 domain, use the following line:

wrapper.java.additional.211=-Dopb.executor.RestExecutorDomain-2.0.remote.debug.params="-agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,address=5006,suspend=n"
If these lines aren't available in the file, manually add them; if the lines are available but commented out, uncomment them.
